entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: I started the Perl Weekly newsletter 14 years ago and (the precursor of) the Perl Maven site 20 years ago. Recently I started to write a booklet about OOP in Perl. I love providing consulting, development, and training services to companies, but I still prefer creating free content. I could do more of the latter if you also supported me. There are several ways to do that. You can do it via Patreon, GitHub, PayPal, or by buying one of my books.

entries.text: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Clear Digits" and "Title Capital". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
entries.title: The Weekly Challenge - 330

entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Counter Integers" and "Nice String" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
entries.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 329

entries.author: adam_russell
entries.text: A creative and playful dive into string processing in Perl. The code is modular, well-commented, and structured using Literate Programming style fragments.
entries.title: Let’s Count All of Our Nice Strings

entries.author: ali
entries.text: The solutions are crisp, Perlish, and demonstrate a good grasp of regular expressions and bitwise logic.
entries.title: TWC329

entries.author: arne_sommer
entries.text: The post tackles both parts of the challenge with thoughtful code and helpful inline commentary. It's Well-documented, beginner-friendly and a good demonstration of Raku’s expressiveness.
entries.title: Counter Nice

entries.author: jaldhar_vyas
entries.text: Solutions leaned toward succinct, readable Perl and Raku idioms. The variety of strategies—regex, loops, data structures—showing the languages’ flexibility.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 329

entries.author: jorg_sommrey
entries.text: The use of uniqint over a simple digit-matching regex is clean and effective—an elegant one-liner that does exactly what's needed without overcomplication.
entries.title: Nice Integers

entries.author: luca_ferrari
entries.text: Raku solutions are idiomatic and concise, leveraging regex and built-ins elegantly. An outstanding, well-organized exploration of polyglot programming applied to algorithmic problem solving.
entries.title: mangling strings

entries.author: luis_mochan
entries.text: The post provides elegant and efficient solutions to the tasks, demonstrating a deep understanding of Perl's capabilities. The reflective analysis adds valuable insights into the complexities of problem-solving in programming.
entries.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 329

entries.author: matthias_muth
entries.text: The post balances clarity, correctness and Perl expertise. A great read for anyone interested in clean problem-solving and Perl-specific insights.
entries.title: Counter-Nice

entries.author: packy_anderson
entries.text: The post delivers solid, multi-language solutions to two algorithmic tasks—extracting distinct integers from mixed strings and identifying the longest "nice" substring—with clear thought processes and thorough commentary. The musical theater references and clever title pun, helps make technical content more approachable.
entries.title: It MUST be nice!

entries.author: peter_campbell_smith
entries.text: The post does a great job of highlighting ambiguities in specifications. It identifies potential edge cases (a9a09a) and makes reasonable assumptions while also pointing out how easily such details can be overlooked or underspecified.
entries.title: Fun with strings

entries.author: roger_bell_west
entries.text: It offers a clear, practical walkthrough of the weekly challenge in both Perl and Rust, showing straightforward and idiomatic solutions for each.
entries.title: Nice Counter

entries.author: simon_proctor
entries.text: This blog post is a thoughtful and engaging walk through of Raku solutions to the challenge, woven with personal reflection and a touch of humor. It opens with a heartfelt tribute to the late MST,

entries.author: yitzchak_scott_thoennes
entries.text: A clean, polished walkthrough demonstrating idiomatic solutions with attention to detail—particularly in normalization and edge-case handling. Well written and focused, with practical depth.
entries.title: Y Translate?

entries.author: yitzchak_scott_thoennes
entries.text: An insightful, advanced and enjoyable read—ideal for those who appreciate both performance-aware coding and elegant problem-solving.
